sections.title: Building Financial Independence
sections.subtitle: Creating a foundation for long-term financial security

sections.title: What is Financial Independence?
sections.content: Financial independence means having control over your own money, making your own financial decisions, and having the resources to support yourself. It's not about being wealthy - it's about having autonomy, security, and the ability to make choices that are right for you.

points.title: Your Own Bank Account
points.description: Open an account in your name only at a different bank than your abuser uses. Consider a bank with no physical branches near you for added privacy.

points.title: Income Source
points.description: Secure employment, even part-time. If working isn't possible, explore disability benefits, child support, or assistance programs.

points.title: Emergency Fund
points.description: Start small - even $20 per paycheck adds up. Keep this money separate and secret if you're still in an unsafe situation.

points.title: Financial Knowledge
points.description: Learn about budgeting, credit, banking, and your rights. Knowledge is power and protection.

points.title: Support Network
points.description: Connect with domestic violence advocates, financial counselors, and trusted friends who can provide guidance.

points.title: Legal Documentation
points.description: Secure your own ID, Social Security card, birth certificate, and important documents. Keep copies in a safe place.

sections.title: Creating Your Financial Safety Plan
steps: Open a P.O. Box or use a trusted friend's address for financial mail
Set up online banking with paperless statements
Use a password manager with a strong, unique password
Enable two-factor authentication on all financial accounts
Keep emergency cash hidden in a safe place
Have copies of important documents stored securely outside your home
Know the location of domestic violence shelters and resources in your area
Create a code word with trusted friends/family to signal you need help

sections.title: Employment and Income
sections.content: Having your own income is crucial for independence. If your abuser has sabotaged your employment, document this for legal proceedings. Look for remote work opportunities, flexible schedules, or jobs with on-site childcare. Many domestic violence organizations offer job training and placement assistance.

sections.title: Safety First
sections.content: If you're still in an abusive situation, prioritize safety over financial moves. Work with a domestic violence advocate to create a plan that protects both your safety and your financial future. Never let your abuser know about hidden accounts or escape plans.

sections.title: Long-Term Independence Goals
steps: Build 3-6 months of expenses in an emergency fund
Establish credit in your own name
Create and stick to a budget that reflects your values
Learn about investing and retirement planning
Consider additional education or job training
Work toward stable housing in your own name
Build a support network of trusted advisors
Teach your children about healthy financial relationships

sections.title: Government Assistance Programs
sections.content: Don't hesitate to use available resources. SNAP (food stamps), TANF (cash assistance), Medicaid, housing assistance, and childcare subsidies exist to help people in your situation. These programs can provide crucial support while you build independence.
